title: Jesse Robbins
text:
Jesse Robbins (born 1978) is an American technology entrepreneur and firefighter notable for his contributions in wearable communication, <a href="web%20operations">web operations</a>, <a href="DevOps">DevOps</a>, and <a href="emergency%20management">emergency management</a>.
Career.
Current work at Orion Labs on real-time voice communication.
Robbins is founder & CEO of Orion Labs, a startup which has created a "Real-Life <a href="Communicator%20%28Star%20Trek%29">Star Trek Communicator</a>" called "<a href="https%3A//www.orionlabs.io/">Onyx</a>". He says he "wanted to bring heads-up, real-time communication to everybody" to build "a world powered by voice".
Contributions to web operations and devops.
Robbins worked at Amazon.com with his manager-approved title “Master of Disaster,” where he was responsible for website availability for every property bearing the Amazon brand. He created "GameDay", a project to increase reliability by purposefully creating major failures on a regular basis. Robbins has said GameDay was inspired by his experience & training as a firefighter combined with lessons from other industries and research on <a href="complex%20systems">complex systems</a>, human cognitive stress models, <a href="reliability%20engineering">reliability engineering</a>, and <a href="normal%20accidents">normal accidents</a>. Game day and similar approaches are considered a best practice for large technology companies.
GameDay-like programs have been adopted by many other organizations, including <a href="Google">Google</a>, <a href="Netflix">Netflix</a> (called <a href="Chaos%20Monkey">Chaos Monkey</a>), <a href="Yahoo">Yahoo</a>, <a href="Facebook">Facebook</a>, and many others.
After Amazon, Robbins founded the Velocity Conference to advance the field of Web Operations & <a href="DevOps">DevOps</a>. He also founded <a href="Chef%20%28company%29">Chef</a>, a cloud infrastructure automation company. Robbins left his full-time role with the company in 2013 to start a new company, but remains an advisor. Jesse Robbins was also an early investor in <a href="PagerDuty">PagerDuty</a>.
Robbins was recognized in 2011 with the <a href="Technology%20Review">Technology Review</a> <a href="TR35">TR35</a> award for "transforming the way Web companies design and manage complex networks of servers and software" at Amazon.com, founding the Velocity Web Performance & Operations Conference, and founding <a href="Chef%20%28software%29">Chef</a> and serving as the first CEO.
Contributions to disaster response & humanitarian aid.
Robbins volunteered as “Task Force Leader” in <a href="Hurricane%20Katrina">Hurricane Katrina</a>. After he returned, he worked with Mikel Maron and <a href="OpenStreetMap">OpenStreetMap</a> on techniques and patterns to improve technology adoption in disaster response & humanitarian aid. These improvements were adopted by the <a href="United%20Nations%20Joint%20Logistics%20Centre">United Nations Joint Logistics Centre</a> in response to <a href="Cyclone%20Nargis">Cyclone Nargis</a> in 2008 and are now widely adopted. One example was CrisisCommons in response to the <a href="2010%20Haiti%20earthquake">2010 Haiti earthquake</a>.
Awards and recognition.
2012 - Robbins was named as a Top 10 Cloud Computing Leader of 2012 by <a href="TechTarget">TechTarget</a>
2011 - Robbins was selected by <a href="Technology%20Review">Technology Review</a> magazine as one of the top "35 under 35" <a href="TR35">TR35</a> innovators in for his work building fault-tolerant online infrastructure at <a href="Amazon.com">Amazon.com</a> and at <a href="Chef%20%28software%29">Chef</a>.
2010 - Robbins was selected by Business Journal as one of the top "40 under 40" entrepreneurs in 2010 for founding <a href="Chef%20%28software%29">Chef</a> and raising $13 million in venture capital funding.
Robbins was recognized in 2011 with the <a href="Technology%20Review">Technology Review</a> <a href="TR35">TR35</a> award for "transforming the way Web companies design and manage complex networks of servers and software" at Amazon.com, founding the Velocity Web Performance & Operations Conference, and founding <a href="Chef%20%28software%29">Chef</a> and serving as the first CEO.
